text: I am Ava Duvernay the director of Salma
so this is a scene I'd really love and
if I'm honest I probably just loved all
the scenes with King and Coretta one of
the reasons why I love this relationship
so much is because it allows us to
really see King as a man I mean you see
the brother taking out the trash
not you know part of the iconography of
King and so it's it's it's it's
important that we found these places
where we can humanize him where we you
know brought him down from the
mountaintop and and then really you know
onion cased him from marble and really
made him you know breathes and lives as
any man would in his kitchen you know
telling his wife that he's about to
leave on a long trip and here just
working with the extraordinary actors
David Oh yellow and Carmen ejogo to
really find the physicality of this
moment through the blocking and really
try to figure out what could they be
doing in this kitchen as subtext for the
challenges and their relationship and
here's where we found him fumbling in
the cabinets
looking for the trash bag because he
hasn't been home enough to know where
they are and so in this film you get in
the scene you see all the tension
between them and it really comes to the
surface one that he has to tell her that
he's leaving on another trip to go to
Salma and really the truth of the matter
is Coretta you know quite a Scotty was
very supportive of everything that he
did but in my exploration of the
characters it was trying to ask at what
point does it become hard to be the wife
of someone who's who's constantly gone
put these things away on your back now I
didn't realize you were leaving so I and
so on this scene you see some of the the
tension building between them here in
the scene also we start to bring in the
idea of surveillance and the government
watching King and his comrades which is
public record at the counterintelligence
program COINTELPRO a big part of the
narrative here and as we see here I just
got to stop and say look at Bradford
young got that shot name is way bad for
young cinematographer extraordinaire so
but yeah just really bringing the whole
idea of the fact that every move they're
making is being watched and we see that
as this scene ends you know you'll see
why
beyond that in this space we're also
really exploring King's spirituality
obviously he's Reverend dr. Martin
Luther King jr. this pulpit is so much a
part of of how he was projecting himself
to the world he was pastor he was
minister he was psychologist but he also
was strategist tactician prankster he
had an ego he you know was often
depressed and felt the weight of the
movement on his shoulders which we try
to illustrate here but really just the
goal of painting the full picture of him
as a human thing is what we were
striving for in every single thing here
he calls a woman in the middle of the

there's a bit of a misdirect here you
